Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to analyze primary sources and how to do online archival research

I gained a deep insight into the major forces at work in reshaping American medicine in the mid-twentieth century, including how fear of communism, reactions to the revelation of Nazi atrocities, the mobilization for the second world war, the development of the nuclear bomb, and the civil rights movement shaped American understanding of medicine, public health, and disability. I also gained some insight into the available sources, and the work that goes into doing historical research on medical issues.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Lots of primary source analysis practice, very thorough and helpful feedback on papers, films were a great addition
Weaknesses: Class went over time regularly which was difficult especially for those of us with class right after, also wish there was greater coverage of connection between race and health that wasn't just civil rights-oriented

This is a fantastic course. Professor Rogers put together a fascinating and compelling syllabus, and facilitates great conversations. Students who are not too familiar with the history of medicine will benefit from the specific focus on this pivotal time period, and will learn much more than they would in a broad survey class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Accommodations made on the final paper were quite helpful given the difficulty of doing primary source research entirely online

Professor Rogers assigned weekly reading quizzes to ensure we read all the materials thoroughly, which was often a burden during work-heavy weeks, but definitely enhanced the quality of discussions compared to other virtual seminars.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Absolutely. Professor Rogers can be intimidating, but she is extremely knowledgeable and always makes the material compelling. Even if this isn't your area of specialty, it's fascinating to apply a rigorous historical lens to the development of medicine, an institution that impacts us all in so many ways.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
